First, the user started by putting object 0 on the machine, but the light stayed off. Then they added object 1, and still the light was off. Then object 2 was added, still off. When they added object 3, the light turned on. So when all four objects were on the machine, the light came on. But then when they took off object 3, the light went off again. Later, putting just object 3 back on made the light turn on again.

Wait, that's interesting. When all four were on, it worked, but taking off 3 made it stop. Then putting just 3 back made it work. That suggests that object 3 alone is sufficient to activate the machine. Because when they put 3 on by itself, the light came on. But earlier, when they had 0,1,2 on without 3, the light was off. Then adding 3 made it on. So 3 is definitely a blicket.

Now, what about object 1? When objects 0,1,2 were on the machine (without 3), the light was off. Then adding 3 made it on. So the presence of 3 is necessary. If the rule was that at least one blicket is needed, then 3 is a blicket, and the others are not. But maybe the rule is different. For example, maybe the machine turns on only when all blickets are on it. But if 3 is the only blicket, then putting it on alone would activate the machine, which is what happened. So the rule could be that the machine activates if there's at least one blicket on it. In that case, 3 is a blicket, and the others are not. Because when 3 was added, even with others, the machine turned on. But when 3 was removed, even with 0,1,2, the machine was off. So 3 is the only blicket. Therefore, object 1 is not a blicket.
